speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Georgina
text: And I’m Georgina.

speaker: Neil
text: When it comes to sport, there’s something for everyone. Do you play a sport, Georgina?

speaker: Georgina
text: I used to play in a netball team years ago. Now I go jogging and I enjoy swimming too.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes, I go jogging sometimes and I play football, although I’m no Ronaldo!

speaker: Georgina
text: But some sports, the so-called ‘full contact’ sports like rugby, American football and boxing are much more dangerous. Now, the truth about the long-term effects on players who make a career taking heavy tackles or punches to the head is being slowly revealed.

speaker: Neil
text: And the issue of safety in sport was back in the news again recently when Danish footballer, Christian Eriksen, collapsed on the pitch during the 2020 European football championship.

speaker: concussion
text: At the centre of the debate are worries about possible brain damage and dementia caused by concussion - that’s a type of traumatic brain injury caused by a bump or blow to the head and the topic of this programme.

speaker: Neil
text: Boxing, of course, is one of the most dangerous sports, and so my quiz question is about a famous boxer. Born in 1949, this boxer has remained mentally and physically fit despite years of punishment in the boxing ring. But who am I talking about? Is he:

speaker: Neil
text: a) Muhammad Ali

speaker: Neil
text: b) George Foreman?, or

speaker: Neil
text: c) Mike Tyson?

speaker: Georgina
text: I’m not a big boxing fan, Neil, but I’ll say b) George Foreman.

speaker: Neil
text: OK, Georgina, we’ll find out the answer to that question later in the programme.

speaker: Georgina
text: So far, we’ve been talking about heavy full-contact sports like boxing, but the truth is that any sportsperson can get concussed.

speaker: Neil
text: In 2018 hockey player and Olympic gold medallist, Nicola White was involved in a heavy collision with another player during a warm-up match.

speaker: Georgina
text: Here’s Nicola telling her story to Paul Connolly, presenter of BBC World Service programme, The Inquiry:

speaker: off,warped
text: I started suffering headaches, nausea, light sensitivity, noise sensitivity, my balance was off, I just felt terrible. I always used to describe it like I was in Alice in Wonderland, I just felt in such a warped world, it just felt relentless, and it never stopped.

speaker: picking up the pieces.
text: Three years on from that moment of impact, Nicola is still picking up the pieces. Despite seeking advice and treatment from specialists in the field of head trauma, many of her symptoms persist.

speaker: offoff
text: After the collision, Nicola‘s balance was off. When something is off, it’s worse than usual.

speaker: off off
text: And off can also mean ‘bad’, as in ‘this milk smells awful – it’s gone off!’

speaker: warped
text: Nicola felt terrible and her world was warped - strange and unpleasant.

speaker: picking up the pieces -
text: In fact, three years after the accident, she was still picking up the pieces - trying to return to normality after a crisis or collapse.

speaker: Neil
text: Concussion is a problem in many sports - even those like hockey or athletics that are not considered ‘full contact’.

speaker: Georgina
text: But the dangers involved with boxing are far greater. In fact, it’s one of the few sports that has concussion written into the rules.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes, that’s right. When a boxer is knocked down, he has ten seconds to stand up and get his senses together – if he can’t, there’s a good chance he’s concussed.

speaker: Georgina
text: Tris Dixon is a former boxer turned sportswriter. Here he is speaking to BBC World Service programme, The Inquiry, about concussion in boxing. See if you can spot the answer to the quiz question Neil asked earlier:

speaker: as bright as a buttona reserve
text: When you look back through history and you see that Henry Armstrong, Sugar Ray Robinson, Muhammad Ali, Joe Louis all suffered with neurological problems as they got older… but what we also need to find out is why can you have a fighter like George Foreman, who’s now in his seventies, and is as bright as a button after two long hard careers. Why do some people seem to have a reserve that has kept them safe later in life?

speaker: bright as a button
text: Tris mentions some famous boxers who suffered neurological problems in later life… and another boxer who’s still as bright as a button – an expression used to describe someone who’s happy, cheerful, intelligent, and full of energy.

speaker: reserve
text: It seems that some people have a reserve – a supply of energy they keep stored up for use in the future, when it’s needed.

speaker: Neil
text: OK, Georgina, let’s get back to my quiz question – I’m pretty sure you know the answer now?

speaker: Georgina
text: Yes, I think so. Neil asked me which famous boxer, born in 1949, was still mentally alert despite many years of fighting. I guessed it was b) George Foreman.

speaker: Neil
text: Good listening, Georgina!

speaker: bright as a button
text: Thanks, Neil - looks like I’m as bright as a button today!

speaker: concussion
text: Let’s recap the vocabulary from this programme about concussion – atraumatic brain injury caused by a knock to the head.

speaker: off
text: When something is off, it’s bad or worse than usual.

speaker: warped
text: The adjective warped means strange and unpleasant.

speaker: pick up the pieces
text: To pick up the pieces means to try to return to the ways things were before a crisis or collapse.

speaker: reserve
text: A reserve is a supply of something that you kept back until it’s needed.

speaker: bright as a button
text: And finally, someone who’s as bright as a button is very happy and cheerful, intelligent, and full of energy!

speaker: Neil
text: Sounds like our 6 Minute English listeners to me!

speaker: Georgina
text: That’s all for our investigation into concussion in sport, but if you’d like to find out more about the subject you can listen again to the whole programme on the BBC World Service website.

speaker: Neil
text: And if you want to grow your brain power, not get linguistically concussed, why not join us again soon for more topical discussion and useful vocabulary here at 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English! Bye for now!

speaker: Georgina
text: Bye!
